Legal_Issue: Did the Citizenship Judge correctly apply the residency requirement under paragraph 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act?
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed 840 days of presence but was 347 days short. Days before permanent residency count as half-days.
Court_Ruling: The Judge's decision was reasonable and adequately explained
Grounds_for_Claim: Challenged rejection of citizenship application based on residency requirements
Assessment_Factor: Physical presence in Canada for at least 1,095 days during the four years preceding application
Procedural_Issue: Federal Court review of Citizenship Judge’s decision
Evidence_Used: Documentation of days of physical presence in Canada
Application_Basis: Residency calculation including half-days prior to permanent residency
Evidence_Assessed: Insufficient documentation to support claimed days of presence
Governing_Rule: Applicant must be physically present in Canada for at least 1,095 days in the four years before application; pre-PR days count as half
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of sufficient documentation to verify residency claims
Cause_Description: Applicant failed to meet the statutory residency requirement for citizenship
Evidence_Handling: Strict count applied due to insufficient evidence; flexible tests rejected
Evidence_Issues: Incomplete or inadequate proof of physical presence
Residency_Compliance: Not met – 347 days short of required 1,095
Evidence_Assessment: Judge found evidence insufficient to establish compliance with residency requirement
Decision_Rationale: Decision was reasonable and properly explained under the governing law
Decision_Making_Body: Citizenship Judge, reviewed by Federal Court
Evidentiary_Issues: Applicant did not provide adequate documentation to substantiate residency
